title: Film Ogive
question_text:
The graph below (called an ogive) displays the relative cumulative frequency for the number of times a random sample of $30\text{ adults}$ have seen a particular children's film with their kids.

Which of the following statements can be justified by the graph?

choices.text: Ten of the people in the sample have seen the movie one time.
There is an outlier in this distribution. One person has seen the movie ten times.
There is an outlier in this distribution. One person has never seen the movie.
The number of times a person has seen the film increases over time, then stops increasing.

77
%
of the adults in the sample saw the movie
4
or more times.

solution:
When reading an ogive from left to right, we can see that each point adds to the running total for the variable. For example, the point
(
2
,
0.23
)
on this ogive means that
23
%
of people have seen the film two times or less (that's the cumulative part).

The flattening of the curve at
7
,
8
,
and
9
viewings indicates that no one was added into the running total for those numbers. There were some adults who saw the movie six times, but none who saw it
7
,
8
,
or
9
times. Then one person saw the movie
10
times. That person is an outlier in this data set.

Choice 'B' is the correct answer.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' refers to the point
(
10
,
1
)
. This means that
100
%
of the adults in the sample have seen the film
10
times or less.

Choice 'C' is incorrect. The interpretation for the point
(
1
,
0
)
is that no one saw the movie
1
or fewer times.

Choice 'D' is incorrect. An ogive does not show any trends that develop over time.

Choice 'E' would be correct if it said "
77
%
of the adults in the sample saw the movie 4 or fewer times."
